Another nice feature of the @soboleffspaces - Guy analysis is the estimation of P(benefit) bounds in addition to ATE. This can be done in any Observational  Study, since we have both observational and (simulated) experimental data, without the imperfections of physical RCTs. https://t.co/7kgblkJSiH

@f2harrell @OstlundOllie @elmir1omerovic @kaulcsmc @drjohnm @GreggWStone A good example of this benefit is demonstrated by the work of @soboleffspaces, Guy, etal, on Hip Fracture Surgeries CMAJ 2018 August 7;190:E923-32. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.171512
The analysis was done 20 years after the study, using graphical models, which did not exist 20-30 yrs ago.

Qualification: In saying "What statisticians still do not get is the notion if 'inevitability'," I meant
"Some statisticians still do not get...". I'm sure my co-author Nick Jewell, and even some Rubin's disciples (and many more) understand what "necessary assumptions" mean. https://t.co/pWttdc8oYf

What statistician still do not get is the notion of "inevitability", and the distinction between inevitable vs. convenient assumptions. CI researchers criticize assumptions only when they are unnecessary or deliberately obscured. 
2/2

Statisticians fear of "assumptions that are not verifiable" explains a century of paranoia and delinquent neglect of all questions related to causal relationships. CI is all about expressing inevitable assumptions and taking them to their inevitable conclusions. What statist 
1/2 https://t.co/GcKYBnFDip

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell @smueller Yes, they correspond to the same 4 response types: Benefiting, AlwaysSurviving, Doomed & Harmed. The reason for the confusion is that we try to adhere to the vocabulary of the non-compliance literature. We shouldn't have.
@IntuitMachine @JohnPelhamBlack RCTs are an example of interventions without a prior model, and they are not useless, merely limited in what they can deliver at great  cost.

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell @smueller The same exercise applies to the bounds in our paper. One may question of course whether a linear utility function is adequate in one case or another, but the bounds produced and the optimization strategies are the same.

@soboleffspaces The EBM call for integrating "patient values"  was meant as a request of the medical profession to be left alone and allow hand-waving when RCTs fall silent. Little did they know that in 2 decades the integration of "patient values" would be formalized.

@leonpalafox The next book after #Bookofwhy would be Primer https://t.co/XofByb7KEO
Individual chapters can be accessed on the web page. And, if you seek an even more formal text, with the full power and beauty of the causal revolution, see CAUSALITY https://t.co/i1mjsWb7C0

It raises many questions, of course, political, as well as cultural and philosophical but,  from my little corner, one question looms natural: How many authors of the Cochrane Report read #Bookofwhy? Short of implying that that number could make a difference, I'm still curious.

RCTs are back in the news. This time on the pages of the NYT:  The Mask Mandates Did Nothing. Will Any Lessons Be Learned?
https://t.co/NXxSQjq9nk

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell The paper "unit selection" (with Ang Li) is an exercise in Decision Analysis, showing how a utility function can be maximized once we know prob(response type i) i=1,2,3,4. See  https://t.co/MlyGdEjQHD

@GermsAndNumbers @statsepi What's the problem? I got a message from a senior Yale professor of epidemiology, describing to me the history of EBM (which I didn't know) and why he has objections to it, which I found to be sound. I learned new things from his message, and shared. What is wrong?

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell Since the sum of the four proportions is ONE,
only 3 need be estimated. Most importantly, we must leave details aside when we ask methodological questions such as "What is the                  goal of RCT?" . Perhaps this would be the main function of our philosopher.

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell on the uncertainy we have about the next patient, not on the uncertainty we had about patients in the RCT. 
Great Convergence: The goal of RCT is to estimate P(harm|c) and P(benefit|c) of patients likely to enter the operating room.
How we go about it is a different question.
3/3

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell As you can see, we are converging on P(harm|c) and P(benefit|c), not CATE. The only question remaining: proportions from what population? Some claim such population does not exist because we are not sampling at random. Philosophy aside, we obviously need to focus  
2/3

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell I think you have defined the goal of RCT quite clearly: To estimate, given patient's characteristics, three proportions: "(1) those who will get better without treatment, (2) those who will get better only with treatment, and (3) those who will fail to get better..."
1/2

@GermsAndNumbers @statsepi So, they are spreading heretical ideas? Frankly, I've heard such (or worse) heresies from other epidemiologists, not rank-and-file but highly prominent, semi-Gods. I wish we could go by the content of what they are saying (evidence based), not its political implications.
@soboleffspaces I haven't hears about EBM until few weeks ago, except (so I thought) as a self-promoting adjective. I didn't realize some consider it to be a methodology. Wikipedia surprised me.
@GermsAndNumbers @statsepi What is Brownstone known for? Is it a trump-supporting cult? A woke-or-else clan? Please educate me.
@soboleffspaces Yes, it's a good paper. Alex Balke was one of my best students, and this paper was part of his PhD dissertation. Too bad he did not go to academia.

@HL327 @stephensenn Lots for me to absorb and digest in Chapter 13. I would hope though that the "purpose" of RCT will be articulated, not in Odds Ratios, but in terms of what it tells the doctor about the next patient in the operating room.
Congratulations go to nine new laurates of the Franklin Medal in Science: https://t.co/vOF1TLWRGv
@gaurav010x @EecsIisc @IsraelMFA Thanks for posting. I love this picture, it makes me look like a scholar.

The stream of results in causal inference continues to flow week after week. This week's crop is listed here: https://t.co/YnvjAjTOzH. One paper that caught my eyes was "Counterfactual Triviality in Structural Causal Models" by Wu. I was disappointed; why spend time on

@pbleic @ChristosArgyrop @f2harrell @stephensenn @AndrewPGrieve @PavlosMsaouel @soboleffspaces @smueller Social media is a dangerous rope; you use a metaphor in some context and ZOOP, someone is sure to accuse you for the rest of your life for not understanding how things work in "real life". Come on. You really think I haven't met nurses?

Glad you mentioned "non-compliance". Indeed, this was one of the first tasks addressed and solved in do-calculus. See  https://t.co/XUBbu9HOUn. The paper also includes applications to real-life data -- pacifying those who claim such applications are  missing from CI literature. https://t.co/uMEEPynERc

@ChristosArgyrop @f2harrell @pbleic @stephensenn @AndrewPGrieve @PavlosMsaouel @soboleffspaces @smueller Well put: "Not all interventions are amenable to RCTs." I would only top it with "but all RCTs deploy interventions",  and continue with: "Hence we must have a calculus of interventions, if we want to understand RCTs"

@HL327 Is a summary of principles available electronically for the Oxford Handbook of Clinical Diagnosis? I believe the 1st question a philosopher would like to ask is: "What is the purpose of RCT?" and "How do you interpret its finding?". We got stuck on these two last week.

@HL327 I do not have personal experience in medicine, yet I often spot a logical flaw when I listen to my doctor's line of reasoning. Philosophers can do better. I hope you are not claiming that  doctors already know how to coherently put together all the evidence they have.

@stephensenn @ChristosArgyrop @pbleic @AndrewPGrieve @PavlosMsaouel @soboleffspaces @f2harrell @smueller Mathematics is not MY TERMS or YOUR TERMS, it is a useful language to communicate ideas unambiguously, even across disciplines.
@trumanfrancis The "change in estimate" is obviously wrong for selecting de-confounders (eg, recall the M bias) but may be good for ranking them, once they are selected with the help of a model.
Good news are quite scarce these days, making this victory a brightener for the rest of the day.

a stolen land?" can one get some idea of what Palestinians mean by "a peaceful two-state solution". https://t.co/PulhHzu1I4

@tdietterich @fchollet One should also mention that graphical models were developed with precisely this problem in mind: Expert systems of the 1970-80s could not 
elicit enough specification rules from experts and, more importantly, could not combine them coherently once elicited.

@HL327 I take it then that you are satisfied with the ability of medical practitioners to formulate the principles of their profession - they do not need help from logicians or philosophers - they are perfectly capable of avoiding circular reasoning like we have seen here on Twitter.

Sorry for the typo, it should have been EBM = Evidence-Based Medicine (not EDM). It actually starts the discussion of EBM with: "There is perhaps no bigger plausibility sham today than “evidence-based medicine" https://t.co/KzMRyjiIxz https://t.co/Oq3M1kcn09
@HAStark Sorry for the typo, it should have been EBM - Evidence-based Medicine.

I am in receipt of an insightful article by Harvey Risch, which illuminates the history of the EDM culture, as well as claims for RCT superiority. https://t.co/NAVV77AIKP 
It evokes new thoughts on our attempts to communicate with hard-core trialists. Worth reading. https://t.co/7c1dOjWKBn

@analisereal Only if we can find a dedicated guest editor to prevent the issue from sliding into another miscommunication, by insisting that contributors answer the questions asked, and not regurgitate what they have been saying all along.
Volunteering?

@soboleffspaces I am not sure they are aware of the circularity looming in the way they are describing their goals. And I don't know how to alert them to it, without offending them. We need someone whom they do not regard as an adversary.

The more we debate the PUPOSE of RCTs, the more convinced I become that the Society of Clinical Trials should organize a conference on: "The logic and philosophy of Clinical Trials." https://t.co/0qMcAcP2b8

I can't see how this clarifies the PURPOSE of RCTs, or the definition of "relative efficacy" as an objective quantity that exists outside the RCT setup, and which the designers of RCTs are attempting to approximate. https://t.co/lwswT2EP50

Fixing broken link to: 
 "Comments on Nick Huntington-Klein's review

Journal of Economic Methodology, 30(1):63--67.
Here is the new link:
https://t.co/5ZiBJjlhJn

@f2harrell @Raamana_ @stephensenn The sentence "Purpose of RCT: estimate relative efficacy" needs clarification. If order for "relative efficacy" to be a PURPOSE of an estimation exercise, it must be defined somewhere (external to RCT). Otherwise it sounds like: "Purpose of RCT: estimate whatever it estimates".

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell @AngeloDalli @Raamana_ What's wrong with it? It saves some people and kills others, the former and the latter are each 10% of the population and, obviously, non-intersecting.  Do we really need to say it at such length? Let's get to the meet of things and ask: Can we devise a test for the two models?

@HL327 @stephensenn @f2harrell @AngeloDalli @Raamana_ If you are referring to the example in our paper, then my conclusion is somewhat different: The FDA should license the drug for all females and lounch a study to explore the existence of features E and F that produce benefit in some males and harm in others.

@stephensenn @HL327 @f2harrell @AngeloDalli @Raamana_ None of the above. It's an innocent question for readers with intellectual curiosity:
Devise a test to determine which model is behind our data.
Model-1 – The drug has no effect whatsoever on any individual 
Model-2 – The drug saves 10% of the population and kills another 10%.

@sim0ngates @f2harrell @HL327 @stephensenn @AngeloDalli @Raamana_ It is a wider comment, suggesting that RCTs as well as all other available sources of data (eg, Observational Studies) be leveraged coherently to answer the research question at hand. By "coherently" I mean using the logic of causal inference.
@heckerma1 @PSpirtes I got a broken link, can you check?
